practice-routine.html.title: Practice Routine(s)
practice-routine.html.body:
Practice Routines
A collection of ideas / exercises to do at intervals, for generic practice.

penatonic shapes run through
pentatonics, adding in root notes
pentatonics starting from different parts of fretboard
major scale run through
major noticing the root notes
major noticing the intervals
major playing over modal chords
major scale calling out the individual notes
go through the different seventh chords
go through intervals taking note of the shapes

lesson-6b-7th-chords.html.title: Lesson 6 - 7th Chords
lesson-6b-7th-chords.html.body:
7th Chords
On the 6th String

MAJOR
MAJOR SEVEN
MINOR
MINOR SEVEN
DOMINANT SEVEN

E|----------------------
B|------12--12----------
G|--13--14--13--12--13--
D|--14--14--13--12--12--
A|--14--12--12--14--14--
E|--12--12--12--12--12--
On the 5th String

MAJOR
MAJOR SEVEN (Take the octave, move it down half a step)
MINOR
MINOR SEVEN (Add in the major seventh)
DOMINANT SEVEN (Dominant 7th is major and minor)

E|-----------------
B|--9--9--8--8--9--
G|--9--8--9--7--7--
D|--9--9--9--9--9--
A|--7--7--7--7--7--
E|-----------------

lesson-23-cantaloupe-island.html.title: Lesson 23 - Jazz / Cantaloupe Island
lesson-23-cantaloupe-island.html.body:
Cantaloupe Island
Backing

Minor 3rd voices (1 fret differences on these strings)

Notes
Scales you'll need in order to

F Minor pentatonic (+blues note) - starts position 4 on A fret 8
D Flat Major (Mixolydian) - starts on 9th fret on the E
D Minor pentatonic (+ blues note) - starts 10th fret on the E
F Minor pentatonic (+blues note) - starts position 4 on A fret 8

Notes on chord annotion

If it has a number (it's a seventh)




Practice

Add Dorian into both minor pentatonics
Learn the backing (chords and how to play them)
Try to blend the progressions into one another
Put the dorian "note" into (which one?)
Learn the major / minor 3rd shapes (relevant in the intro)
Add Dorian into both the F and D Minor

Questions

Learn the full pentatonic
Learn the full major
What defines if you can do a keychange?
FMinor 7 (Pentatonic)
How do I map from the mixolydian to the F# Major? ()

Call out the roots within the pentatonics (1-5)

Play major in the second octact (bottom 3)

lesson-27-chords-for-modes.html.title: Lesson 27 - Chords For Major Modes
lesson-27-chords-for-modes.html.body:
Diatonic in G

Ionian - G Major 7
Dorian - A minor 7/13
Adding in the 13th adds in the "Dorian" note


Phyrigian - Flat 9
"Technically cheating" as has an extra note outside of G Major


Lydian - C Major 7 Sharp 11
When ever you hear sharp 11 think "Lydian"


Mixolydian - D Dominant 7
Add in some chromaticism


Aeolian - Minor 7
Locrian - Minor 7 Flat 5 (or "half diminished")

Int-1--2--3---4--5---6---7--

E|------------7--10---------
B|--3--7--7---7--12--12--1--
G|--4--5--8---9--10--12--2--
D|--4--5--10--9--10--12--2--
A|-----7--9------10--14-----
E|--3--5--7---8--10--12--2--
Questions:

How do you remember the associated chords with the modes? Just from mathematically working out the intervals?
Why chromatic for mixolydian?
It's funny how these chords are starting to sound more normal...

questions.html.title: Questions
questions.html.body:
Questions

Why is a chord major or minor?
Is there a rhyme or reason to which finger you "lift off" for the sevenths?
What should I focus on? Pentatonics? Modes? Chord shapes? What's the long term plan?
